taxonomicNotes: There is currently a publication in review on the species delineation of Menidia conchorum and Menidia peninsulae (S. O'Leary pers. comm. 2013).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

White et al. (2017) concluded that Mobula rochebrunei (East Atlantic Devilray) is a junior synonym of M. hypostoma (Atlantic Devilray), with the latter species being confirmed as occurring in both the Western and Eastern Atlantic.
A sibling species is known from Langebaan, but has yet to be named and published (W. Holleman pers. comm. 2010).
This species was described in 2002, and little information exists about it.
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008)
The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/color differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

The Dusky Shark is extremely similar genetically and morphologically to the Galapagos Shark (Carcharhinus galapagensis). These species share mitochondrial DNA haplotypes but are distinguishable based on single nuclear polymorphisms (SNPs) (Corrigan et al. 2017) and also occupy different habitats (insular vs. continental).
This is the revised taxonomic concept of Centrophorus grandulosus, which includes C. lusitanucs as a junior synonym; C. lesliei and C. longipinnis are also now split out as newly recognised species.
Genetics studies have led some researchers to suspect that there may be an undescribed species of Echinorhinus off Oman and elsewhere in the Arabian Sea region (Henderson et al. 2016).

Squalus mitsukurii was once considered a globally distributed species, but recent morphological and genetic work suggests the species is restricted to temperate waters of Japan and Korea, and is possibly endemic to the Northwest Pacific (Pfleger et al. 2018, Ziadi-Künzli et al. 2020). The resolution of the species-complex is ongoing with further species likely being described in the future.

This species has been mistaken mainly for Dasyatis (=Hypanus) say but also for Dasyatis pastinaca in the past. The specific name has been misspelled as hipostigma, including in the original description.
The scientific name for this species is often misspelled as Carcharhinus perezii. Carcharhinus springeri Sadowsky & Amorim 1977 is considered a synonym (Soto 2001).

The spellings Dipturus trachyderma and Dipturus trachydermus have been used for this species. The basionym is Raja trachyderma and the valid name is Dipturus trachydermus following grammatical rules. While Fricke et al. (2019) use Dipturus trachyderma, we follow Last et al. (2016) which correctly uses Dipturus trachydermus.

There has been much disagreement concerning the relationships of the one family placed in order Mugiliformes (Nelson 2006). Although reasons exist for regarding mugilids as perciform, rather than being related to the Atherinomorpha, there seems to be insufficient reason to change the classification from that given in Nelson (1994), based on Stiassny (1993) and Johnson and Patterson (1993) (Nelson 2006).

This species is treated by some authors as being a synonym of the more widespread Liza melinoptera (Valenciennes, 1836).

Fernholm treats the genus Paramyxine Dean, 1908 as a synonym of Eptatretus Cloquet 1819 (Fernholm 1998, Fernholm and Quattrini 2008), while other authors treat Paramyxine as a valid genus (Wisner 1999, McMillan and Wisner 2004, Kuo et al. 2010). Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) follow Fernholm's advice on this and place all Paramyxine species within Eptatretus. This results in some duplicate names: E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. wisneri (Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994) (formerly Paramyxine wisneri Kuo, Huang & Mok 1994); and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004 and E. fernholmi (Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994) (formerly Paramyxine fernholmi Kuo, Huang & Mok, 1994). To resolve this issue, both E. wisneri McMillan 1999 and E. fernholmi McMillan & Wisner, 2004, as the more recent descriptions, need to be renamed.

The current IUCN Red List retains the genus Paramyxine until the above taxonomic work has been completed.

The Banggai Cardinalfish has eight dorsal spines, 14 dorsal soft rays, two anal spines, and 13 anal soft rays (Koumans 1933). This species is distinguished further by having a tasseled first dorsal fin and a deeply forked caudal fin. Both the second dorsal fin rays and anal fin rays are elongate. The colour pattern is quite distinctive with three black bars across the head and body, black edges along the anterior margins of the second dorsal and anal fins, black edges along the upper and lower margins of the caudal fin, and black pelvic fins marked with white spots. A series of similar white spots run along the edges of the second dorsal, anal and caudal fins (Allen and Steene 1995, Allen 2000). The body is silvery and contains about 20 brilliant whitish dots between the second and third black bars. Dots of each individual have a unique disposition that can be used for specimen identification (Vagelli 2002). Body size of adults reaches 80 mm total length and 55 mm standard length (SL) (Allen 2000). Secondary sexual dimorphism has not been demonstrated for this species (Vagelli and Volpedo 2004).

The genus Pterapogon contains only one other species, P. mirifica from northwestern Australia. However, ongoing studies on the reproductive biology, behaviour, anatomy and preliminary data on molecular studies on P. mirifica (A. Vagelli, pers. comm. on 27th Feb 2007) indicate that it is distantly related to the Banggai Cardinalfish and may in fact merit separate generic status. Therefore the Banggai Cardinalfish may be unique at the generic level.
Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).
This species was recently described and all evidence indicates that it is endemic to the Pelican Keys in Belize (Randall and Lobel 2003).

There is an ongoing discussion on the validity of the hamlets as biological species (Domeier 1994). Hamlet "species" are defined primarily on differences in color patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them.
Formerly called Raja circularis. Early papers often confused Leucoraja circularis and Leucoraja naevus.
Pomatoschistus tortonesei was redescribed and separated from P. bathi (Miller 1982).

The populations of this species in Australia and South Africa may represent two different species (Farmer 2008, Barnes et al. 2015). Argyrosomus amoyensis is most likely a junior synonym of A. japonicus (Taniguchi and Okada 2984, K. Sasaki pers. comm. 2016).
Mkare et al. (2017) found that genetic admixture between estuaries was high, and recommend recognizing the subpopulations from the three estuaries as a single Evolutionarily Significant Unit (ESU).
Further work is needed for a taxonomic review of the genus Evynnis (Iwatsuki et al. 2007).
This species was recently described as distinct from the very similar E. evelynae and E. genie based on results from DNA barcoding (Victor 2014).
This species was recently described based on results from DNA barcoding (Victor 2014) and resembles T. multifasciatus.

This species was recently described based on results from DNA barcoding. It had been considered to be conspecific with E. horsti and also closely resembles E. louisae (a sympatric species) in appearance (Victor 2014).

This species is poorly represented in collections. The lack of specimens has caused some nomenclatural problems that have not been fully resolved. Older scientific names may apply to earlier growth stages of this species.

Carcharhinus dussumieri is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).

The previously, monotypic genus Manta was re-evaluated with two species identified, Reef Manta Ray (Manta alfredi) and Giant Manta Ray (Manta birostris) (Marshall et al. 2009). Genetic evidence supported the separation (Kashiwagi et al. 2012). Both species have broad global distributions and are sympatric in some locations and allopatric in others (Kashiwagi et al. 2011, Lawson et al. 2017). A third species of manta ray has also been proposed (Marshall et al. 2009) with increasing genetic support (Hinojosa-Alvarez et al. 2016, Kashiwagi et al. 2017, Hosegood et al. 2018). Genetic evidence has also resulted in the genus Manta being subsumed within the genus Mobula (Poortvliet et al. 2015, White et al. 2018).

Due to the recent taxonomic changes, both present day and historical reports can often be unclear and without adequate descriptions, photographs or geographic locations, it can be difficult to conclusively attribute fisheries data to a single species. Care should be taken when using reports or accounts of the Giant Manta Ray. Melanistic (black) and leucistic (white) colour morphs occur in all species of manta ray (Marshall et al. 2009). Variant colour morphs often contribute an added degree of confusion when attempting to visually discriminate between species of manta rays in the field or in photographs, especially when close examination is not possible. It should be noted that these colour morphs could be a source of error, resulting in misidentifications in past or future studies or surveys of distribution.

Revision of Squalus in the Indo-Australasian region resulted in the resurrection of S. montalbani (Philippines, Indonesia, Australia) and S. griffini (New Zealand) and the description of S. chloroculus Last, White & Motomura, 2007. These species were previously considered to be conspecific with S. mitsukurii, which this work has revealed, does not occur in Australasian waters. Continued investigation of Squalus mitsukurii from around the world is resulting in more taxa being recognized.

Hamlet species are defined primarily on differences in colour patterns. They are known to interbreed and hybridize freely with very little consistent genetic differentiation amongst them. Prior to its description, it was confused with the phenotypically-similar Hypoplectrus gemma (Domeier 1994). A recent genomic analysis of H. maya confirms it is a distinct evolutionary lineage from other Caribbean hamlet species, including H. nigricans, H. puella, H. unicolor and H. gemma (Moran et al. 2019).

The genus Lucifuga is known as one of the most diverse of stygiobiotic fishes. The systematics of Lucifuga may still be incomplete due to the relatively common discoveries of new species. Garcia-Machado et al. (2011) concluded that Lucifuga spp. are genetically divergent, but with some of the species being morphologically indistinguishable and recommends revisiting the taxonomy of the genus. A revision of the Lucifuga spp. of Cuba with the description of a new species is currently in preparation by Hernández et al. (Hernández, D., Casane, D., García, A., Chevalier-Monteagudo, P., Møller, P. R. and García-Machado, E.). Recently a species from eastern Cuba, formerly described as a variety of L. dentata, was described as a new species, L. gibarensis (Hernández et al. 2020). The species appears to be more closely related to Bahamian species, than to the other Cuban species. 

There are no species of Lucifuga spp. on Little Bahama Bank other than L. lucayana and the other Bahamian species L. spelaeotes separated from L. lucayana by the deep waters of the Providence Channels (Møller et al. 2006).
Last et al. (2016a) resurrected the species Telatrygon crozieri (Blythe, 1886) from its former synonymy with Dasyatis (=Telatrygon) zugei.

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

This species was mistakenly named Dasyatis macrophthalma in the title of the original description. A correction note was provided by Rosa et al. (2000).
Last et al. (2016a) placed Himantura heterurus, H. imbricata, H. javaensis, and H. walga within their newly described genus Brevitrygon.
Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, comprised of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including macrura).
This species requires further taxonomic research and it is possible that populations in the Mekong and other drainage systems may pertain to other species (Vidthayanon et al. 2016).
This species was previously confused with Pastinachus sephen with which it co-occurs (Last and Manjaji-Matsumoto 2010).
Aetomylaeus milvus is considered to be distinct from A. maculatus (Last et al. 2016).

Historically, it has been argued that American Eels (Anguilla rostrata) and European Eels (A. anguilla) may be conspecific (vertebral count differences were believed to be entirely ecophenotypic); this has now been shown to be incorrect by a number of studies. Separate species status has been confirmed by demonstrations that American and European Eels comprise two largely separate gene pools (see Avise et al. 1990, Bastrop et al. 2000, Avise 2003, Bernatchez et al. 2011). Eels in Iceland include, in low frequency, the products of hybridisation between American and European Eels (Avise et al. 1990, Avise 2003, Albert et al. 2006, Pujolar et al. 2014). Phylogenies of the genus Anguilla based on mitochondrial DNA have shown the two species to be distinct, although more closely related than most species of the genus (Aoyama et al. 2001, Minegishi et al. 2005).

The preponderance of evidence indicates that American Eels do not exhibit significant geographic or latitudinal patterns of genetic variation (Avise et al. 1986, Avise 2003, Wirth and Bernatchez 2003, Côté et al. 2013). However, Côté et al. (2015) suggest that there may be minor quantitative genetic differences between American Eels colonising different parts of the range despite the fact that all belong to a single genetic population. They consider that plausible explanations for this pertain either to non-random dispersal or to selective mortality based on individual genetic differences. They further emphasize that on one hand, evidence for panmixia justifies the need for global co-operative action toward improved management and conservation of the species, but that on the other hand, evidence for local genetically based phenotypic differences also justify the need for local actions (Côté et al. 2015).
The Pezichthys species as a group are relatively newly described, and further taxonomic resolution is needed (Last and Gledhill 2009).
The Pezichthys species as a group are relatively newly described, and further taxonomic resolution is needed (Last and Gledhill 2009).
The taxonomic status of this nominal species requires clarification (H.K. Larson pers. comm. 2019).
Haploblepharus edwardsii is commonly misidentified for other Haploblepharus species.

Mustelus mustelus and M. asterias are morphologically similar and may be misidentified. Many early works may refer to either of the two species (Wheeler 1978). Mustelus asterias is distinguished from M. mustleus by a narrower inter-narial space and the presence of white spots on the dorsal and upper lateral sides of the former.

There is a demonstrated high level of contemporary and historical misidentification of unspotted Mustelus asterias as M. mustelus in the Northeast Atlantic Ocean region (Farrell et al. 2009, Farrell 2010). There are no reliably confirmed records of M. mustelus occurring north of Portuguese waters (Farrell 2010). Quignard and Capapé (1972) described a M. mustelus specimen from Portuguese Atlantic Ocean waters based on dermal denticle morphology and this remains the most northerly reliably identified record of this species. Similarly, some misidentification can occur between M. mustelus and M. punctulatus. This is because the black spots on the body are not unique to M. punctulatus and their absence is not diagnostic for M. mustelus. The distance of the nostrils and the shape of the mouth appear to be more useful features to distinguish the two species during fieldwork (Marino et al. 2018).

Taxonomy of the genus Centrophorus has been much controverted during the last fifty years. Part of the confusion has been focused on two species with sessile dermic denticles (thus different from C. squamosus) whose most conspicuous anatomic differences are maximum size and size at sexual maturity. The species assessed here is to be considered the “smaller” species, and has been recently reported under the name of C. granulosus or C. uyato. In Australia, this species has been referred to as C. zeehaani.

Taxonomic confusion comes from a long history of mistakes in the literature but also from a problem of nomenclature. A recent review by White et al. (2013) included a re-description and the settlement of a neotype of the “larger species” as C. granulosus (Bloch and Schneider 1801). Nomenclature status of this species is pending a paper in preparation that is based on classic taxonomy, review of nomenclature and genetic data, and that will also include a re-description of the species (Guallart et al. 2013, Veríssimo et al. 2014).

At present this assessment is presented under the name C. uyato (Rafinesque 1810) pending this review. It must be noted that this species is assumed not to fit the description made as Squalus uyato by Rafinesque (1810) but its first descriptions of reference are those made as Spinax uyatus by Bonaparte (1834) and Müller and Henle (1839) as C. granulosus.
No taxonomic notes.
This species was previously considered to be conspecific with Aetobatus narutobiei, but the species have since been shown to differ genetically and morphologically (White and Moore 2013).
This species is considered distinct from Aetomylaeus milvus (Last et al. 2016).

This species belongs to the long-snout group of Centrophorus which includes C. harrissoni, C. isodon, C. seychellorum, and C. westraliensis. The long-snout species group requires further taxonomic attention (White et al. 2017).

The Oxynotus recorded as O. centrina from Angola, Namibia, and South Africa may not be that species but an undescribed one, differing from O. centrina in having a much shorter interdorsal space. If this is correct, the records of O. centrina from tropical West Africa need to be reexamined, but until the problem is resolved the southern and southwestern African Oxynotus is retained in O. centrina (Bass et al. 1976).

Squalus brevirostris from the northwest Pacific has previously been considered a synonym of S. megalops. A revision of Indo-Pacific Squalus species and molecular data revealed that this species is clearly separable from the true S. megalops from Australia (Last et al. 2007, Weigmann 2016). Misidentifications of the Squalus species in the Northwest Pacific is an issue and may affect the quality of data available for this species.

Combined morphological and molecular data led Last et al. (2016) and White et al. (2017) to conclude that M. eregoodootenkee is a junior synonym of M. kuhlii. However, Hosegood et al. (2019) suggested these were separate species, which was supported by Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. (2020), who also clarified the nomenclature as M. eregoodoo.
Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, comprised of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including pastinacoides).

Formerly a monotypic genus (containing only Urogymnus asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) moved five more medium to large species to Urogymmus, including lobistomus. This species is probably misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) uarnacoides and Himantura (=Pateobatis) hortlei (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007).
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

The taxonomy of Lamiopsis has recently been resolved with White et al. (2010) resurrecting and redescribing Lamiopsis tephrodes from Southeast Asia, and Akhilesh et al. (2016) redescribing Lamiopsis temminckii from the Arabian Sea. This species is potentially endemic to the Arabian Sea, however, further taxonomic work is required in the Bay of Bengal to determine if this species occurs there or if recorded specimens refer to L. tephrodes.
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Iwatsuki et al. (2011) revised the genus Platyrhina, describing two new species as distinct from Platyrhina sinensis.

This species is similar to  the Leopard Whipray (H. leoparda) (Last et al. 2016). The Honeycomb Whipray juveniles of 50 cm disc width (DW) have a well-developed main denticle band with inconspicuous primary denticles while the adults have a strong pattern of large ocelli and reticulations.

Sympatric to the Little Skate, immature specimens of the two species are often confused, especially females. However, chance of misidentification decreases as they mature. Disk is rounded, with many small dark spots on upper surface. Usually 1-4 ocelli are found on the upper surface on each side of disk, each with a dark brownish center and pale edge. Young have long middorsal row of large spines on disk and tail. Upper jaw has 72 rows of teeth. Lower surface is usually white but marked with irregular pale brownish blotches (although this colouration is found in several other species within range).

Previously this species was referred to as a subpopulation of Holohalaelurus regani (occurring off KwaZulu-Natal and southern Mozambique). A revision of the genus Holohalaelurus has shown that this species is in fact distinct from H. regani (Human 2006). Specimens of H. favus were first referred to and illustrated by Bass et al. (1975).
Ishihara et al. (2012) established the new genus Beringraja for the two species B. binoculata  (previously Raja binoculata Girard, 1855) and B. pulchra (previously Raja pulchra Liu 1932).
The revision of the genus Holohalaelurus showed that H. polystigma is a junior synonym of H. punctatus (Human 2006).
No taxonomic notes.

Himantura uarnak was recently split from other Himantura species (Last et al. 2016a). The new distribution no longer includes Australia and Papua New Guinea (Last et al. 2016b). There is some continued taxonomic uncertainty with the Himantura genus and this assessment should be updated if the current distribution changes.

Raja miraletus was considered wide-ranging in the Eastern Atlantic, but is a species-complex with R. miraletus occurring in the Northeast Atlantic and the Mediterranean Sea, R. parva occurring off West Africa, and R. ocellifera off South Africa (Last and Séret 2016).

The new taxonomic concept for Squatina guggenheim includes S. punctata as a junior synonym.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).

This species is often misidentified with the Taiwan Angelshark (Squatina formosa). Diagnostic features for this species include pelvic fin tips which extend to origin of the first dorsal fin and angular pelvic, dorsal, and caudal fins (Walsh et al. 2011).

Although there are records of Australian specimens of Narrow Sawfish (Anoxypristis cuspidata) with broader triangular rostral teeth than normal, the analysis of genetic data from this region did not produce any evidence that there is more than one species present (D’Anastasi 2010).

The Dwarf Sawfish (Pristis clavata) is similar to the Smalltooth Sawfish (Pristis pectinata), with which it may have been previously confused, but it has fewer rostral teeth than the Smalltooth Sawfish (Last and Stevens 2009).
Coilia mystus is easily confused with the co-occurring C. nasus (Whitehead et al. 1988).

The scientific name of this species has been contested in the past. In China, it has been referred to by Coilia ectenes (Whitehead et al. 1988).

There are taxonomic uncertainties surrounding the species of Coilia present in China, Korea, and Japan. For the purposes of this assessment, we are treating C. nasus as being distributed in China, Korea, and Japan, as treated in Whitehead et al. (1988).

authority: Del Moral-Flores, Ramíz-Antonio, Angulo & Pérez-Ponce de León, 2015
taxonomicNotes: Morales-Flores et al. (2015) described Ginglymostoma unami as distinct from Ginglymostoma cirratum. Ginglymostoma unami is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and G. cirratum to the Atlantic.
This species is part of the Eviota nigriventris complex (Greenfield 2017) and is closely related to E. pamae and E. bifasciata (Allen 2001, Allen et al. 2013).
This species was previously misidentified as Upeneus guttatus and U. bensassei (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).

The nomenclatural history of the species is somewhat complicated. The name Stegostoma fasciatum (Hermann, 1783) has been the standard name used, however Dahl et al. (2019) concluded that the original name Stegostoma tigrinum Forster, 1781 is the correct senior synonym.
The Longfin Gulper Shark is recently described (White et al. 2017). An extremely long-based first dorsal fin is distinctive and distinguishes it from other Centrophorus species.

Combined morphological and molecular data led Last et al. (2016) and White et al. (2017) to conclude that Mobula eregoodootenkee is a junior synonym of M. kuhlii. However, Hosegood et al. (2019) suggested these were separate species, which was supported by Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. (2020), who also clarified the nomenclature as M. eregoodoo.

The taxonomy of Lamiopsis has recently been resolved with White et al. (2010) resurrecting and redescribing Lamiopsis tephrodes from South-east Asia, and Akhilesh et al. (2016) redescribing Lamiopsis temminckii from the Arabian Sea.
This species was previously considered a subspecies of the Pacific Bluefin Tuna (Thunnus orientalis) or Atlantic Bluefin Tuna (Thunnus thynnus).
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List with the incorrect spelling of regani.

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, comprised of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including gerrardi). Reports of the species are often confused with the Coach Whipray (Himantura uarnak).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, comprised of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including bleekeri). Previously on The IUCN Red List bleekeri was treated as a junior synonym of uarnacoides (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007). However, Pateobatis bleekeri is considered a valid species by Last et al. (2016). This species was formerly referred to as Himantura alcockii/Himantura uarnacoides in the Arabian Seas region.

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, comprised of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including uarnacoides). Previously on The IUCN Red List, bleekeri was treated as a junior synonym of uarnacoides (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007). However Pateobatis bleekeri is considered a valid species by Last et al. (2016). This species is misidentified for Himantura lobiostoma, Pateobatis hortlei and Maculabatis pastinacoides (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007).

Hemitriakis indroyonoi is separable from the other congeners, H. abdita, H. complicofasciata, H. falcata, H. japanica and H. leucoperiptera, by a combination of vertebral counts, morphometric characters, and juvenile colouration (White et al. 2009).

Silfvergrip (2009) described the diagnostic features of A. japonica greater than 200 mm total length (TL). These include a plain colouration, with no distinct markings, and a total number of vertebrae between 112–119. Dorsal fin anterior margin is 8.5–9.5% of TL, in advance of anus. The mouth is small, about one fourth of head length, and distance from anus to end of tail is 5.6–6.0 times longer than distance from anus to dorsal fin insertion.

Recent revisions of the taxonomy of genus Mobula included the decision to consider the circumglobal Spinetail Devil Ray M. japanica (Müller & Henle, 1841) a junior synonym of the Mediterranean Giant Devil Ray M. mobular (Bonnaterre, 1788), causing M. mobular to become a circumglobal species (Poortvliet et al. 2015, Hosegood et al. 2018, White et al. 2018).

Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. (2020) argued that one of the traits that were used to support the differentiation between the two species, the maximum size of M. mobular purportedly in excess of 5 m disc width (DW), can be explained by past misidentifications of M. birostris, and therefore unsubstantiated. This also supports their recommendation to retain for the species the common name “Spinetail Devil Ray” instead of “Giant Devil Ray”.
The taxonomy of this species remains unresolved and it may prove to be a synonym of the Smallspot Numbfish Narcine maculata (Last et al. 2016).
This species has been split from Gymnura micra and is morphologically similar but can be distinguished on the basis of clasper morphology and disc shape (Yokota and de Carvalho 2017).

Concha et al. (2019) synonymised the genus Zearaja with Dipturus based on morphological and molecular analyses, thus assigning species formerly in the genus Zearaja to Dipturus.

The species Dipturus chilensis was formerly considered occurring in both the Southeast Pacific and the Southwest Atlantic. However, Gabbanelli et al. (2018) resurrected Raja brevicaudata Marini, 1933 from Argentina out of synonymy with D. chilensis and Concha et al. (2019) described Dipturus lamillai Concha, Caira, Ebert & Pompert, 2019 as a distinct species from the Falkland Islands (Malvinas), Southwest Atlantic. Therefore, D. chilensis is restricted to the Southeast Pacific, from central Chile to the Strait of Magellan, and references to D. chilensis in the Southwest Atlantic refer either to D. brevicaudatus or D. lamillai.

The Whitespotted Eagle Ray (Aetobatus narinari) (Euphrasen 1790) was originally restricted to the Western Central and Southwest Atlantic (Sales et al. 2019) but the range now also extends to the eastern Atlantic (Fricke et al. 2020).
